Manx: ORIGINAL MANKS.
English: (Train’s) LITERAL TRANSLATION.

Manx: MANNANAN BEG
English: LITTLE MANNANAN

Manx: MAC Y LEIRR;
English: SON OF LEIRR;

Manx: NY, SLANE COONTEY JEH
English: OR, AN ACCOUNT OF THE

Manx: ELLAN VANNIN;
English: ISLE OF MAN;

Manx: SOILSHAGHEY,
English: SHOWING,

Manx: Cre’n Mayll v’er ny Mannanee da Man-
English: What rent the Manks Inhabitants paid to

Manx: nanan; kys ren Noo Parick eshyn
English: Mannanan; and how St. Patrick ban-

Manx: y imman ersooyl as e Heshaght; kys
English: Ished him and his company away; and how St. Patrick established Christianity first in the Island.

Manx: hug Parick ayn Creestiaght; as Coon-
tey jeh ny chied Aspickyn va ’syn Ellan.
Myrgeddin coontey jeh’n chied Ree va
English: Also, an account of the first King that was in the Island, and his posterity; and how the Island came to the Stanley Family.

Manx: Mannin, as E Lhuight; coontey jey
ny Chiarnyn, as kys kaink yn Ellan
gys Clein Stanley
The following is a translation of the lines as they stand in the Manks song, without any regard to the poetry in English:—
Dy neaishtagh shiu agh rish my Skeayll,
English: If you would listen to my story,

Manx: As dy ving lhieu ayns my Chant:
English: I will pronounce my chant

Manx: Myr share dy voddyms lesh my Veeal,
English: As best I can, I will, with my mouth,

Manx: Yinnin diu geill da’n ELLAN SHEEANT.
English: Give you notice of the enchanted Isle.

Manx: Quoi yn chied er ec row rieau ee,
English: Who he was that had it first,

Manx: Ny kys eisht myr haghyr da;
English: And then what happened to him;;

Manx: Ny kys hug Parick ayn Creestiagh,
English: And how St. Patrick brought in Christianity,

Manx: Ny kys myr haink ee gys Stanlaa.
English: Or how as it came to Stanley.

Manx: Mannanan beg va Mac y Leirr,
English: Little Mannanan was the Son of Leirr,

Manx: Shen yn chied er ec row rieau ee;
English: That was the first that ever had it;

Manx: Agh myr share oddym’s cur-my-ner,
English: But as best as I can observe,

Manx: Cha row eh hene agh An-chreestee.
English: He himself was a heathen.

Manx: Cha nee lesh e Chliwe ren eh ee reayll,
English: It was not with his sword he kept it,

Manx: Cha nee lesh e Hideyn, ny lesh e Vhow;
English: Neither with arrows or bow;

Manx: Agh tra aikagh eh Lhuingys troailt,
English: But when he would see ships sailing,

Manx: Oallagh eh ee my geayrt lesh Kay.
English: He would cover it round with a fog.

Manx: Yinnagh eh Dooinney ny hassoo er Brooghe
English: He would set a man, standing on a hill,

Manx: Er-lhieu shen hene dy beagh ayn Keead;
English: Appear as if he were a hundred;

Manx: As shen myr dreill Mannanan keoie,
English: And thus did wild Mannanan protect,

Manx: Yn Ellan shoh’n-ayn lesh cosney Bwoid.
English: That Island with all its booty.

Manx: Yn Mayll deeck dagh unnane ass e Cheer,
English: The rent each landholder paid to him was,

Manx: Va bart dy Leaogher-ghlass dagh bleiu;
English: A bundle of coarse meadow grass yearly;

Manx: As eisht shen orroo d’eeck myr keesh,
English: And that, as their yearly tax,

Manx: Trooid magh ny Cheery dagh Oie-Lhoine,
English: They paid to him each midsummer eve.

Manx: Paart ragh lesh y Leoagher seose,
English: Some would carry the grass up

Manx: Gys yn Slieau mooar ta heose Barrool;
English: To the great mountain up at Barrule:

Manx: Paart elley aagagh yn Leoagher wass,
English: Some others would leave the grass below,

Manx: Ec Mananan erskyn Keamool.
English: With Mannanan’s self, above Keamool.

Manx: Myr shen eisht ren adsyn beaghey,
English: Thus then did they live;

Manx: O er-lhiam pene dy by-veg nyn Geesh;
English: O I think their tribute very small,

Manx: Gyn Kiarail as gyn Imnea,
English: Without care and without anxiety,

Manx: Ny doggyr dy lhiggey er nyn Skeeys.
English: Or hard labour to cuase weariness.

Manx: Eisht haink ayn Parick nyn meayn,
English: Then came Patrick into the midst of them:

Manx: She Dooinney-noo v’eh lane dy Artue,
English: He was a saint, and full of virtue,

Manx: Dimman eh Mannanan er y Tonn,
English: He banaished Mannanan on the wave,

Manx: As e ghrogh Vooinjer dy lieh-chiart.
English: And his evil servants all dispersed.

Manx: As jeusyn ooilley dy row olk,
English: And of all those who were evil,

Manx: Orroo cha ren eh veg y Ghrayse;
English: He showed no favour or kindness,

Manx: Dy row jeh sluight ny Buch-chrout,
English: That were of the seed of the conjurers,

Manx: Nagh ren eh stroie as coyrt dy baase.
English: But what he destroyed or put to death.

Manx: Vannee eh’n Cheer veih Kione dy Kione,
English: He blessed the country from end to end,

Manx: As rieau cha daag eh Boght ayn-jee;
English: And never left a beggar in it:

Manx: Dy row jeh lhuirid Lhannoo beg,
English: And, also, cleared off all those

Manx: Dy dob rieau dy ve ny Creestee.
English: That refused or denied to become christians.

Manx: Shen myr haink y chied Chredjue Mannin,
English: Thus it was that christianity first came to Man,

Manx: Ec Parick Noo er ny chur ayn;
English: By Saint Patrick planted in,

Manx: As Creest dy niartagh aynin eh,
English: And to establish Christ in us,

Manx: As neesht myrgeddin ayns nyn Gloan.
English: And also in our children.

Manx: Eisht vannee Parick Karmane noo,
English: He then blessed saint German,

Manx: As daag eh eh nyn Aspick ayn;
English: And left him a bishop in it,

Manx: Dy niartagh yn Credjue ny smoo as ny smoo,
English: To strengthen the faith more and more,

Manx: As Cabballyn ren eh anrick ayn.
English: And faithfully built chapels in it.

Manx: Ayns dagh treen Balley ren eh unnane,
English: For each four quarterlands he made a chapel

Manx: Da’n Sleih shen-ayn dy heet dy ghuee;
English: For people of them to meet to prayer;

Manx: Myrgeddin ren eh Keeil Charmane,
English: He also built German Church, in Peel Castle,

Manx: Ta ayns y Pheeley foast ny soie.
English: Which remaineth there until this day.

Manx: My dug Karmane er e Obbyr kione,
English: Before German had finished his work,

Manx: Hug Jee fys er as hooar eh baase;
English: God sent for him, and he died,

Manx: Myr shoyn diu hene yn Chaghter chion
English: As ye, yourselves, know that this messenger,

Manx: Cha vel fer ain hed jeh lesh Saase.
English: Cannot be put of by using means.

Manx: Hooar eshyn baase as t’eh ny lhie,
English: He died, and his corpse was laid,

Manx: Raad by vooar y treih ve cha leah er n’in shley
English: Where a great bank had been, but seen was levelled;

Manx: Crosh dy Chlagh te’c e gha Chass,
English: A cross of stone is set at his feet

Manx: Ayns e Cheeill hene foast ayns y Pheeley.
English: In his own church, in Peel Castle.

Manx: Eisht hank Maughold ayn myr beer,
English: Then came Maughold, we are told,

Manx: As ghow eh Thalloo ec y Chione;
English: And came on shore at the Head;

Manx: As hrog eh Keeill as Rollick mygeayrt,
English: And he built a church and yard around,

Manx: Yn Ynnyd by-vian lesh beaghey ayn.
English: At the place he thought to have his dwelling.

Manx: Ny Cabballyn doardee Karmane noo,
English: The chapels which Saint German ordered,

Manx: Da’n Sleih Shen-ayn dy heet dy ghuee;
English: For the people to come to prayers in them,

Manx: Hug Maughold shiartanse jeu ayns Unnane,
English: Maughold put a parcel of them into one,

Manx: As myr shen ren eh Skeeraghyn cooie.
English: And thus made regular parishes.

Manx: Hooar Maughold baase as t’eh ny lhie,
English: Maughold died and he is laid

Manx: Ayns e Cheeill hene neesht ec y Chione;
English: In his own church too, at the Head;

Manx: As y nah aspick haink ny-yei,
English: And the next bishop who came after,

Manx: Myr share shioune dooys she eh va Lonnan.
English: To the best of my knowledge, was Lonnan.

Manx: Connanghan yn nah er eisht haink ayn;
English: Connaghan then came next,

Manx: A haink Marooney reesht yn trass;
English: And then Marown the third;

Manx: T’ad shen nyn droor ayns Keill Marooney
English: There all three lieth in Marown,

Manx: As ayns shen vees ad dy bra vaght.
English: And there forever lieth unmolested.

Manx: Nish lhig mayd shaghey ny Deiney-noo,
English: Now we will pass by these holy men,

Manx: As chymney mayd nyn Anmeenyn gys Mac Yee,
English: And commit their souls to the Son of God,

Manx: Cha nheeu Fir agglish voylley ny smoo,
English: It profiteth not to praise them more

Manx: Derrey hig ad fenish Ree dagh Ree.
English: Until they appear before the King of Kings.

Manx: Myr shen eisht ren adsyn beaghey,
English: Thus then did they live or pass their time,

Manx: Gyn Dooinney ayn yinnagh orroo corree;
English: No man that would molest or anger them,

Manx: Agh goll dy gheddyn pardoon veih’n Raue,
English: But going to get a pardon from Rome,

Manx: Er-derry haink eh huc Ree GORREE.
English: Until there came to them King Gorree.

Manx: Lesh e Lhuingys hrean as Pooar y Ree,
English: With his strong ships and king’s command,

Manx: As ghow eh Thalloo ec y Laane;
English: And came on shore at the Laane;

Manx: Shen y chied er ec row rieau ee,
English: He was the first that ever had it,

Manx: Dy ve ny Ree er yn Ellan.
English: To be a King of the Island.

Manx: Cha geayll mee dy ren eh skielley ec Purt,
English: I never heard that he did any injury at a harbour,

Manx: Chamoo ren eh marroo ayn jee;
English: Neither did he kill any in the Island;

Manx: Agh aym sis dy daink jeh Sluight,
English: But I know that there came of his race,

Manx: Three Reeaghyn jeig jeh Ree GORREE.
English: Thirteen Kings of King Gorree.

Manx: Eisht haink ayn Quinney as haink ayn Quaill,
English: Then came Quinney, and then came Quayle,

Manx: Haink towse dy Lheigh as Reill ayn jee;
English: There came a measure of law and rule,

Manx: Ny Keeshyn mooarey as y Mayll
English: With greater taxes and greater rents,

Manx: Vees dy hirrey dy bragh er Dooinney dy bee.
English: That will forever be demanded of the men that be.

Manx: My ta red erbee jannoo Skielley diu,
English: If anything doeth you harm,

Manx: Cur-jee nyn Mollaght er Mannanee;
English: Give your curse upon the Manksmen;

Manx: She ad by-vessey da’n Ellan Sheeant
English: They were the worst for the enchanted Island,

Manx: Ec dagh drogh Leigh ’yannoo ayn jee.
English: By making each bad law in her.

Manx: Eisht haink ayn Ollister mooar Mac Ree Albey,
English: Then came Great Ollister, son of the King of Scotland,

Manx: Lesh Lhuingys hrean dy braue ayn jee;
English: With strong shipping he bravely came;

Manx: As er-lhiam pene dy by-voo lesh Foalsaght,
English: But I think myself it was more by falsehood,

Manx: Cha nee lesh Dunnallys smoo chragh eh ee.
English: And not by courage he made most havoc.

Manx: Cha daag eh bio jeh sluight y Ree,
English: He left not living, of the King’s seed,

Manx: Mac ny Inneen d’ymmyrkey Kiona;
English: A son or daughter to carry his head;

Manx: Agh un Unnane myr baare dod ee,
English: Excepting one, who, as best she could,

Manx: Hie dy hirrey Cooney gys Ree Goal.
English: Went to seek for help to the King of France.

Manx: O Albanee my vow uss feeu,
English: O, Scotchman, if thou wert worthy,

Manx: As dy Haghter ec dy heet ayn;
English: And as a messenger when thou didst come,

Manx: Cammah nagh durree oo as ve dy Ree,
English: Why didst thou not stop and be our king,

Manx: Myr vow O ree, as Mac Ree Laughlin.
English: As thou, O, King, wert son of king Laughlin.

Manx: Agh s’beg eh lhiam, dy veg eh lhiat,
English: But I care but little, that hou thought’st it little,

Manx: Ny Fee ’ve rock, rock erskyn dy Ching;
English: The ravens to croak, croak above thy head,

Manx: Agh lhig dooys loayrt jeh’n Inneen gring
English: But let me speak of the mentioned girl,

Manx: Neeayr as nagh daag oo bio agh ee;
English: Since thou didst not leave alive but she;

Manx: Haink jeh Sluight Ree Laughlin,
English: Of all the seed of  King Laughlin,

Manx: As v’ee Inneen da Ree Gorree.
English: And she was daughter to King Gorree.

Manx: Chia leah as chragh y Noid y Cheer,
English: As soon as the enemy spoiled the country,

Manx: Nagh jagh eh roish as daag eh ee;
English: Did he not go away and leave it?

Manx: Myr yinnagh y Sowin choo rish e Quallan,
English: As the she greyhound would do with her whelp,

Manx: Eh aagail ny lhie er Beggan Bree.
English: And leave him lying with little strength.

Manx: Cha leah as chragh y Noid y Cheer,
English: As soon as the enemy spoiled the country,

Manx: Nagh jagh eh roish noon gys Nolbin;
English: Did he not go over to Scotland?

Manx: As ghow ish Lhuingys neesht myr beer,
English: And she too shipping, and to the best that I know,

Manx: As hie ee rhimbee gys Ree Hocsyn.
English: And she went over to the King of England.

Manx: Cha leah as raink ee gys y Choort,
English: As soon as she arrived at court,

Manx: Ren eh j’ee soiagh dy feer choar;
English: He entertained her with great kindness,

Manx: As daa ny Deiney haink maree,
English: And to the men that came with her,

Manx: Hug y Ree palchey dargid’s d’oar.
English: He gave plenty of silver and gold.

Manx: Nagh ren eh fenaght j’ee quoi v’ee,
English: He then asked her who she was,

Manx: Ny cre vo heilkin gys e Choort;
English: Or what was her business to the court?

Manx: Ta mish dooyrt un Inneen da Ree,
English: She answered, I am a King’s daughter,

Manx: Erreish ve Spooilt, as gyn Kiannoort.
English: I have been robb’d, and without a protector.

Manx: She mysh dty Vyghin as dty Ghrayse,
English: It is to thy mercy and thy grace,

Manx: Ta mish nish lhoobey hoods, O Ree;
English: That I do humbly sue to thee, O King;

Manx: Cha vel mee geearree Mie ny Maase,
English: I do not ask for good or wealth,

Manx: Agh geearee ort dty Chymmey, Ree.
English: But crave of thee for thy pity, O King.

Manx: She dty Vea hooin, dooyrt Ree Hoscyn,
English: Welcome to us, says the King of England,

Manx: As ren eh poosey ish myr beeu;
English: And he married her very soon,

Manx: Vee Sluight Laughlin, Inneen Gorree,
English: She was of the seed of Laughlin, the daughter of King Gorree,

Manx: Rish Sir William dy Vountegue.
English: By Sir William de Montague.

Manx: Eisht Sir William va Ree Vannin,
English: Then Sir William was King of the Isle of Man,

Manx: Cha hoie eh jee agh beggan feeu;
English: But he thought but little of it,

Manx: Son chreck eh ee, as ghow eh Maase,
English: For he sold it, and bought cattle,

Manx: O ree red bastagh dy ren rieau.
English: Which was a pity that ever he did.

Manx: Rish yn Chiarn Scroop chreck eshyn ee,
English: To Lord Scroop he sold it;

Manx: O ree nagh moal hug saynt da Maase;
English: O King, how simple to covet cattle;

Manx: Ga ve ayns foayr mooar rish y Ree,
English: Altho’ he was in great favour with the King,

Manx: Gerrit ny-yei hur eshyn baase.
English: It was but a short time until he suffered death.

Manx: Agh fys nyn Gooishyn cha vel aym,
English: But their matters I do not know,

Manx: Lhig dauesyn sailliu fysseree;
English: Let those who please prophesy;

Manx: Agh aym ta sys er shoh dy feer,
English: But this I know right well;

Manx: Dy row lane Maase seihlt ec y Ree.
English: That the King had a vast number of cattle.

Manx: Haink yn Ellan eisht gys y Ree,
English: Then the Island came to the King,

Manx: Conaant Scroop myr shoh dy jarroo,
English: Scroop’ss covenant appointed so,

Manx: Nagh beagh ny sodjey echey j’ee
English: That he should have no more of it,

Manx: Ny veagh e vio-hys er y Thalloo.
English: Than during his life on Earth.

Manx: Haink yn Ellan reesht gys y Ree,
English: The Island then came to the King;

Manx: As mooar y bree cha row echey ayn;
English: But he had no great authority in it;

Manx: Hug eh da Earl Northumberland ee,
English: Because he gave it to the Earl of Northumberland;

Manx: Agh cha dug eh ee da e Chloan.
English: But he did not give it to his children.

Manx: Adsyn veagh dunnal ayns Caggey,
English: Those who would be courageous in wars

Manx: Yioghe ad Giootyn mooar myr bailliu;
English: They get great presents if they would;

Manx: Agh ayns Caggey mooar Sal’sbury,
English: But in the great war at Salisbury,

Manx: Va Earl Northumberland er ny varroo.
English: The Earl of Northumberland was killed.

Manx: Quoi hagher eisht gys y Vagher,
English: Who happened then to come to the field,

Manx: Agh Sir Juan Stanley cosney Bwoid;
English: But Sir John Stanley, well fitted;

Manx: Myr by-vannee haink er y Laa,
English: As that day proved a blessing to him,

Manx: Lesh e Chliwe geyre ve sheer goll trooid.
English: As he went by with his sharp sword.

Manx: My Ree, by-veg er hene nyn Mea,
English: My King, he lttle thought of life,

Manx: Yiaragh eh Dooinney sheese dyn Glare;
English: He would cut a man down without speaking,

Manx: Varragh eh lesh un vuilley Shleiy,
English: He would with one blow of spear;

Manx: Cabbyl as Dooinney gys y Laare.
English: Take to the ground both man and horse.

Manx: Cre dy aase veagh Claiggin e Ching,
English: Whatever growth his head might be;

Manx: Gyn King cha ragh eh-ass;
English: Without heads he would not go away;

Manx: Ny cre by eillit veagh e Ghreem,
English: Or however harnessed his back might be,

Manx: Roashagh e Chliwe geyre e Chress.
English: His sharp sword would reach his girdle.

Manx: Tra scuirr y Magher, as ghow eh fea,
English: When the field was quiet and had taken rest,

Manx: Eisht boggey mooar ayn hene ghow’n Ree;
English: There the king rejoiced greatly himself;

Manx: As deie eh huggey Sir Juan Stanley,
English: And he called to him Sir John Stanley,

Manx: Dy ghoaill eh Leagh jeh Maase as Nhee.
English: To take his pledge of cattle and goods.

Manx: Kyndagh dy vel uss er my rere,
English: Because thou hast served me well,

Manx: Sheer cosney Bwoid dooys, as dhyt hene;
English: And gained booty for me and for thyself;

Manx: Gow son dy Leagh Ellan Vannin
English: Take for thy portion the Isle of Man,

Manx: Son Leagh dy hogher dy bragh beayn.
English: To be for thee and thine for ever.

Manx: Shen myr haink yn Ellan gys nyn Laue
English: Thus the Island came to their hands,

Manx: As shen myr haink Clein Stanley ayn;
English: And thus the Stanley’s name came in;

Manx: As Ree lurg Ree freayal shin veih Gaue,
English: And King after King keeping us from danger,

Manx: As mooarane Bleeantyn Chiarnane ayn.
English: And many years Lords in it.

Manx: Eisht tra hooar Sir Juan Stanley baase,
English: Then, when Sir John Stanley died,

Manx: Haink reesht Sir Juan geiyrt er e Vac;
English: Then came again Sir John, his son,

Manx: Va mooarane Blein heear ayns Neirin,
English: Who had been many years in Ireland;

Manx: Ny Lieutenant feer ooasse oc.
English: A very noble Lieutenant there.

Manx: Eisht haink Thomase Derby Ruggerey Ree,
English: Then came Thomas Derby, born King,

Manx: Eh-hene va ceau yn Cribble Oar;
English: ’Twas he that wore the golden crupper;

Manx: Cha row un Chiarn ayns Socsyn ’sthie,
English: There was not one Lord in England itself

Manx: Lesh whilleen Gymman-glioon cheet ny chear,
English: With so many knee-guineamen coming in his country.

Manx: Er Albanee chooilleen eh Clea,
English: On Scotchmen he avenged himself;

Manx: As hie eh noon gys Keel choobragh;
English: And he went over to Kirkcubright,

Manx: As ren eh lheid y chladdagh Thie’n,
English: And he made such havoc of houses,

Manx: Dy vel paart ayn foast gyn Mullagh.
English: That some of them are yet unroofed.

Manx: Nagh bwaagh shen dasyn Dooiney-aeg,
English: Was not that pretty in a young man

Manx: Yn Clea chooilleen my by-vooar e Ghraine;
English: To revenge himslef while he was but young,

Manx: Roish haink rieau er o Ghob Faasaag,
English: Before he beard had grown round his mouth,

Manx: As e gheiney ’chur lesh as dy slane.
English: And to carry his men home with him whole.

Manx: Ayns un Thousane Queig Cheead as Shiaght,
English: In one thousand five hundred and seven,

Manx: She ayns Mee ny Boaldiney ve;
English: And it was in the month of May,

Manx: Ghow eh Thalloo ayns Roonyssvie,
English: He came on shore at Derbyhaven,

Manx: Er Boirey’n Theay hug eh slane Fea.
English: And put a full end to the commotion of the public.

Manx: Lheid y Thie as dreill eshyn hene,
English: Such a house as he kept himslef,

Manx: Dy Ree ny Ruggerey dy hreg ny nrean;
English: For a King, or down to a low degree,

Manx: Cha vaik sleih lhied rish Milley Blein,
English: People never saw for countless years,

Manx: Chamoo hee reesht ’syn Earish ain.
English: Neither will again in our days.

Manx: Agh arragh dy voylley cha jean yms ny smoo,
English: But any more praise I will not give

Manx: Choud as sbooie dooiney seanish my Hooill;
English: So long a I live among men,

Manx: Er-aggle dy dagher daue rhym y ghra,
English: For fear they may tell me

Manx: Dy nee son Leagh vein sheer brinooile.
English: That it is for gain I make so much flattery.

Manx: Agh faag-ym da’n nagh Ghooinney hig my Yei
English: But I leave the man that cometh after me

Manx: Dy voylley hene  myr sheagh chur da;
English: To praise him as he will find him worth;

Manx: Tra vees e Chress ny lhie ’syn oaie,
English: When his crest will be laid in the grave,

Manx: Yiew’n Dooinney Bwoid myr sheagh cur da.
English: He will get the glory he deserveth to have.
